children.name: limit
children.definition: to stop a number or amount from becoming too large, or stop someone from doing whatever they want: giới hạn
examples: ▪ The new law limits the number of foreign cars that can be imported.
▪ Men hold most of the top jobs, and this limits women’s opportunities for promotion.
limit sb/sth to sth
▪ Let’s limit our discussion to the facts in the report.
limit yourself to sth
▪ As you look for material to write about, don’t limit yourself to other people’s ideas.
set/impose/put a limit[] to control the size or amount of sth, or to control an activity, by deciding what the limits of it will be: đặt ra giới hạn
set/impose/put a limit on
set/impose a limit of sth
set/impose a limit
Governments should put strict limits on tobacco advertising.
The courts have imposed limits on school officials’ power to dismiss teachers.
The president set a time limit of 6 months for the negotiations to produce an agreement.
Parents need to know when to set limits for their children’s behavior.

children.name: restrict
children.definition: to strictly control and limit the size, amount, or range of something: hạn chế
examples: ▪ The law would restrict the sale of handguns.

children.name: restrict somebody/something to something
examples: ▪ This year’s AIDS conference is restricted in size to fewer than 3,000 participants.

children.name: restrict yourself to something
examples: ▪ McGregor has said he will voluntarily restrict himself to $2.2 million in campaign spending.

children.name: keep to
children.definition: /keep within  if you keep to or keep within the limits of something, you make yourself stay within those limits: giữ cho ở trong (giới hạn)
examples: ▪ We need to keep to the schedule if we’re going to finish on time.
▪ Keep within the speed limit and you should have no problems.

children.name: confine
children.definition: to keep something within the limits of a particular activity or subject, especially when it is difficult for you to do this: hạn chế, quản thúc

children.name: confine somebody/something to something
examples: ▪ Rebel troops have confined their attacks mainly to the southern part of the country.

children.name: confine yourself to something
examples: ▪ The report confines itself to known and verifiable facts.

children.name: fix
children.definition: to decide on the limit of something, especially something that often changes, and make it stay the same for a long time: giới hạn (đặt ra một cách ổn định)
examples: ▪ Interest rates for savings accounts have been fixed at 7% for the rest of the year.
▪ The project has finally been approved and the budget has been fixed.

children.name: restriction
children.definition: 1 a rule or law that limits or controls what people can do
examples: restriction on
restrictions on immigration
a 50 mphspeed restriction
trade/travel restrictions
impose/place restrictions on something
The law imposed new financial restrictions on private companies.
strict/tough/tight restriction
tougher restrictions on alcohol advertising
lift/remove a restriction
Restrictions on trade were lifted.
2[U] when you restrict the size, amount, or range of something

children.name: put/place restrictions on something
examples: The authorities placed strict restrictions on diamond exports.

children.name: impose restrictionsformal
children.definition: put restrictions on something
examples: Some countries have imposed restrictions on advertising aimed at children.

children.name: introduce restrictions
examples: Nine other states now plan to introduce similar restrictions.

children.name: lift/remove restrictions
examples: He promised to lift restrictions on press freedom.

children.name: tighten restrictions
children.definition: make them stricter
examples: The government recently tightened restrictions on police use of firearms.

children.name: relax/ease restrictions
children.definition: make them less strict
examples: There are restrictions on travel to Cuba by American citizens.

children.name: a restriction applies to somebody/something
examples: These travel restrictions don’t apply to tourists.

children.name: severe/strict restrictions
examples: The regime had put severe restrictions upon the media.

children.name: tough restrictions
children.definition: strict
examples: He called for tougher restrictions on contributions to political parties.

children.name: petty restrictions
children.definition: that seem unreasonable and unnecessary
examples: The removal of petty restrictions has made it much easier to do business.

children.name: speed restrictions
examples: Drivers are ignoring speed restrictions.

children.name: an age restriction
examples: Employers can no longer place age restrictions on applicants.

children.name: trade restrictions
children.definition: on the sale of goods between countries
examples: Trade restrictions between the islands were removed.

children.name: import/export restrictions
children.definition: trade restrictions
examples: Import restrictions on manufactured goods have been lifted.

children.name: travel restrictions
examples: The Home Secretary placed travel restrictions on supporters with convictions for violence.

children.name: planning restrictions
children.definition: legal restrictions on what buildings can be built somewhere
examples: There are government proposals to relax planning restrictions on green belt areas around cities.

children.name: parking restrictions
examples: Are there parking restrictions in the city centre?

children.name: cramp sb's style
children.definition: crampsb'sstyleinformal humorous
examples: to prevent someone from enjoying themselves as much as they would like, especially by going somewhere with them

children.name: hold
children.definition: nounCONTROL

children.name: limitation
children.definition: the act or process of controlling or reducing something

children.name: limitation to
examples: Any limitation to the king’s power could be permanent.

children.name: constraint
children.definition: sth that limits your freedom to do what you wantSYN restriction: hạn chế
examples: constraint on
Constraints on spending have forced the company to rethink its plans.
the constraints of family life
financial/environmental/political etc constraints
There have been financial and political constraints on development.
impose/place constraints on somebody/something
constraints imposed on teachers by large class sizes

children.name: financial/legal/economic etc constraints
examples: During the war, there were many physical and social constraints on citizens.

children.name: time constraints
children.definition: the limited amount of time that is available
examples: Exams are always done under strict time constraints.

children.name: budget constraints
children.definition: the limited amount of money that is available
examples: With any new project, you have to be aware of the budget constraints.

children.name: a major constraint
examples: In Egypt, the shortage of land and water is a major constraint on agriculture.

children.name: a serious/severe constraint
examples: The country's debts put serious constraints on its economic growth.

children.name: a tight constraint
children.definition: a strict limit
examples: They were operating within tight financial constraints.

children.name: an important constraint
examples: Their religious beliefs were an important constraint on their behaviour.

children.name: impose constraints on somebody/something
examples: You have to work within the constraints that the software imposes.

children.name: place/put constraints on somebody/something
examples: Lack of funding is putting severe constraints on research.

children.name: free somebody/something from constraints
examples: Summer vacation is a time when children are freed from the constraints of routine.

children.name: be subject to constraints
children.definition: be limited by them
examples: Teachers are subject to the constraints of the examination system.

children.name: be free from constraints
children.definition: not be limited by them
examples: No film producers are free from the constraints of censorship.

children.name: given the constraints on something
children.definition: because there are particular constraints on something
examples: Given the constraints on space in the city, most people live in tiny apartments.

children.name: constrain
children.definition: 1to stop someone from doing what they want to doSYN restrict

children.name: constrain somebody from doing something
examples: Financial factors should not constrain doctors from prescribing the best treatment for patients.
2to limit somethingSYN restrict:
Poor soil has constrained the level of crop production.
Women’s employment opportunities are often severely constrained by family commitments.

children.name: keep to swh
children.definition: keep tosomewherephrasal verb

children.name: to stay in one particular area
examples: _Please keep to the footpaths.

children.name: keep sth down
children.definition: keepsthdownphrasal verbSIZE

children.name: to control the size or number of something and prevent it from increasing
examples: _We need to work hard to keep our prices down.

children.name: steady
children.definition: adjectiveCONTROLLED

children.name: under control
examples: _a steady voice/look/gaze You need steadynervesto drive in city traffic.
_Painting these small details needs a steadyhand.

children.name: when you agree to do sth if sth else happens
on condition that
children.definition: if you agree to do something on condition that something else happens, you will only do it if this thing happens:
examples: với điều kiện là
▪ Ron lent me the money on condition that I paid it back within three weeks.
Ron đã cho tôi mượn tiền với điều kiện là tôi sẽ phải trả trong vòng ba tuần
▪ General Motors agreed to supply trucks to the Chinese government on condition that they altered their pricing policy on cars.
Bộ trưởng xe có động cơ đã đồng ý cung cấp xe tải cho chính phủ Trung Quốc với điều kiện là họ phải sửa đổi chính sách thuế trên xe hơi
on one condition if this one thing is done
với một điều kiện
▪ You can borrow the car on one condition - that you promise to be back before midnight.
Anh có thể mượn chiếc xe với một điều kiện - là anh phải hứa sẽ trả lại trước nửa đêm

children.name: be conditional on
children.definition: /upon   if an offer, agreement, or someone’s permission is conditional on something else, it will only be given if something else happens:
examples: sẽ được thực thi với điều kiện là
▪ Offers of financial aid were conditional upon the company changing its management structure.
Những đề xuất viện trợ tài chính sẽ được thực thi nếu công ty thay đổi cấu trúc quản lý
▪ Permission to use firearms is conditional on the consent of the Chief of Police.
Giấy phép sử dụng súng cầm tay sẽ được thực thi với điều kiện là có sự cho phép của Cảnh sát trưởng
conditional[adjective] có điều kiện
▪ They have made us a conditional offer
Họ làm cho chúng tôi một lời đề nghị có điều kiện

children.name: unconditional
children.definition: unconditional surrender/release/agreement etcan agreement or offer that is unconditional is made without any conditions: vô điều kiện
examples: unconditionally[adv] một cách vô điều kiện
If you are not completely satisfied with our service, we will unconditionally refund your money.

children.name: The general said he would fight on until the enemy agreed to an unconditional surrender
examples: They are campaigning for the unconditional release of all political prisoners.

children.name: no strings attached
children.definition: if you offer something or ask for something with no strings attached, you offer it or ask for it without stating any conditions and without trying to get an advantage for yourself: không ràng buộc, vô điều kiện

children.name: Emergency food aid should be given with no strings attached
examples: Before you accept the loan you’d better make sure that there are no strings attached.

children.name: limiting
children.definition: 1preventing any improvement or increase in something:
examples: Alimiting factorin health care is the way resources are distributed.
2informalpreventing someone from developing and doing what they are interested in :
The job’s OK, but it’s sort of limiting.

children.name: restrictive
children.definition: often disapproving sth that is restrictive stops people doing what they want to doSYN limiting:
examples: Many members thought the rules were too restrictive.

children.name: a restrictive policy on admission to the college
examples: He is self-employed because he finds working for other people too restrictive.
The college is not able to expand because of restrictive planning laws.

children.name: methods, laws etc that are used to control situations or people
controls U
children.definition: controls
examples: các biện pháp kiểm soát
controls on:các biện pháp kiểm soát về
▪ Within months, most of the wartime controls on trading were abandoned.
Trong vòng vài tháng, hầu hết các kiểm soát từ thời chiến về thương mai đã bị bỏ đi
rigid controls:strict controls : các biện pháp kiểm soát chặt chẽ về
▪ Rigid rent controls ensured that no one paid too much for housing.
tight controlsstrict controls.các biện pháp kiểm soát chặt chẽ về
Các biện pháp kiểm soát tiền thuê chặt chẽ đảm bảo rằng không ai phải trả quá nhiều tiền thuê nhà ở
▪ The government is proposing to introduce even tighter controls on immigration
Chính phủ đang đề xuất đưa ra những kiểm soát chặt chẽ hơn về nhập cư.

children.name: restraints
children.definition: laws, beliefs, or customs that control an activity or situation, especially by not allowing people to do exactly what they want to do:
examples: sự kiềm chế, áp chế , gò bó
restraints on :sự kiềm chế, áp chế , gò bó về
▪ Every society has its own restraints on moral behaviour.
mọi xã hội đều có những hạn chế riêng về hành vi đạo đức
restraints of : sự kiềm chế, áp chế , gò bó về
▪ The economy is beginning to grow again after the restraints of the war.
Kinh tế đang bắt đầu tăng trưởng trở lại sau những hạn chế do chiến tranh
impose restraints:introduce rules in order to control someone or something: đưa ra áp chế
▪ As they grow older, kids begin to rebel against the restraints imposed by their parents.
Khi họ lớn lên, bọn trẻ bắt đầu nổi loạn chống lại những áp chế do bố mẹ chúng đặt ra.
